item.title: By: Michael van Lent
item.dc:creator: Michael van Lent
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/glass/#comment-180135">Daniel Reeves</a>.
Thanks very much. Just placed my order. We'll see what can be done with today's google glass and how it can show the promise for the future.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Daniel Reeves.

Thanks very much. Just placed my order. We’ll see what can be done with today’s google glass and how it can show the promise for the future.

item.title: By: Daniel Reeves
item.dc:creator: Daniel Reeves
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/glass/#comment-180003">Zachary Paul</a>.
Zach, so sorry, I ran out of invitations! I can tell you though that the bone conduction thing is complete crap. You can hear the computer generated voice fine (as can anyone next to you!) but you can't have a phone conversation via Glass. It's so bad that the next iteration apparently has a normal earbud that you can plug in.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Zachary Paul.

Zach, so sorry, I ran out of invitations! I can tell you though that the bone conduction thing is complete crap. You can hear the computer generated voice fine (as can anyone next to you!) but you can’t have a phone conversation via Glass. It’s so bad that the next iteration apparently has a normal earbud that you can plug in.

item.title: By: Daniel Reeves
item.dc:creator: Daniel Reeves
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/glass/#comment-180008">Brian Noble</a>.
Invitation on the way! I'm pretty nervous about people using such things while driving but for GPS navigation it doesn't seem any worse than a dashboard mounted device.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Brian Noble.

Invitation on the way! I’m pretty nervous about people using such things while driving but for GPS navigation it doesn’t seem any worse than a dashboard mounted device.

item.title: By: Daniel Reeves
item.dc:creator: Daniel Reeves
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/glass/#comment-180000">Michael van Lent</a>.
Invitation on the way! I'll be pretty surprised if such a social orthotic is possible with google glass any time soon. But I bet it will be possible eventually so I'm highly in favor of such research!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Michael van Lent.

Invitation on the way! I’ll be pretty surprised if such a social orthotic is possible with google glass any time soon. But I bet it will be possible eventually so I’m highly in favor of such research!

item.title: By: Daniel Reeves
item.dc:creator: Daniel Reeves
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/glass/#comment-179999">Alexei Andreev</a>.
I invited you. Sadly, your first idea is not possible with the current hardware. Your second idea -- starting and stopping a timer -- is possible but I've found that there's surprisingly high friction for waking up the device (tapping it or tilting your head) before you can talk to it. I think a Pebble watch would work better for this.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Alexei Andreev.

I invited you. Sadly, your first idea is not possible with the current hardware. Your second idea — starting and stopping a timer — is possible but I’ve found that there’s surprisingly high friction for waking up the device (tapping it or tilting your head) before you can talk to it. I think a Pebble watch would work better for this.

item.title: By: Brian Noble
item.dc:creator: Brian Noble
item.description: We've done some usability testing of in-vehicle apps. It would be interesting to think of similar work with glass(es), assuming the EULA does not forbid it...
item.content:encoded: We’ve done some usability testing of in-vehicle apps. It would be interesting to think of similar work with glass(es), assuming the EULA does not forbid it…

item.title: By: Zachary Paul
item.dc:creator: Zachary Paul
item.description: I'm very intrigued by the Google Glasses, particularly to see how the bone conduction works for sound transmission. I'm deaf in my right ear and wear a removable wireless system that uses a device I wear on my back molars to transmit sound. I'm hoping that technology like this will mean one day in the future I can just have my glasses transmit sound from my deaf side. So #mememe ! Zach Paul
item.content:encoded: I’m very intrigued by the Google Glasses, particularly to see how the bone conduction works for sound transmission. I’m deaf in my right ear and wear a removable wireless system that uses a device I wear on my back molars to transmit sound. I’m hoping that technology like this will mean one day in the future I can just have my glasses transmit sound from my deaf side. So #mememe ! Zach Paul

item.title: By: Michael van Lent
item.dc:creator: Michael van Lent
item.description:
He Dan,
Mike van Lent here. I'd be very interested in an invite for Google Glass if you still have any. I've been working on games for autism spectrum assessment and training social skills. I'm wondering if Google Glass might be useful as a Social Orthotic, making social cues more explicit and helping to translate social cues across cultures.
Thanks, Mike
item.content:encoded:
He Dan,

Mike van Lent here. I’d be very interested in an invite for Google Glass if you still have any. I’ve been working on games for autism spectrum assessment and training social skills. I’m wondering if Google Glass might be useful as a Social Orthotic, making social cues more explicit and helping to translate social cues across cultures.

Thanks,
Mike

item.title: By: Alexei Andreev
item.dc:creator: Alexei Andreev
item.description: One interesting application I want to see on it is being able to gesture with your fingers to highlight a word or text in real world, and then copy it to some buffer / send it as email / look it up in dictionary. This will speed up physical -> digital text transfer significantly. Also, doing day-to-day quantified self stuff will be much easier with Glass. "Ok, Glass, start commute timer" or something like that. I'd love to track how I spend my time on granular basis, but it's too cumbersome/annoying even with a phone right now. #mememe
item.content:encoded:
One interesting application I want to see on it is being able to gesture with your fingers to highlight a word or text in real world, and then copy it to some buffer / send it as email / look it up in dictionary. This will speed up physical -> digital text transfer significantly.
Also, doing day-to-day quantified self stuff will be much easier with Glass. “Ok, Glass, start commute timer” or something like that. I’d love to track how I spend my time on granular basis, but it’s too cumbersome/annoying even with a phone right now.
#mememe

item.title: By: aleksj
item.dc:creator: aleksj
item.description:
If you enjoy science fiction, I'd recommend http://vimeo.com/46304267 for some examples of potential Glass apps - in the gamification vein.
Hopefully Google Glass won't be the Microsoft Tablet PC of tablet computing. Google search results have deteriorated in past years, not improved.
item.content:encoded:
If you enjoy science fiction, I’d recommend http://vimeo.com/46304267 for some examples of potential Glass apps – in the gamification vein.

Hopefully Google Glass won’t be the Microsoft Tablet PC of tablet computing. Google search results have deteriorated in past years, not improved.
